fulltitle: AMD Radeon RX 9070 XT Review, Have They Finally Done It?

comments.text: Update: The test system specs are missing the driver version for the 9070 series, our mistake. That said we obviously used driver version '24.30.31.03' as the older driver doesnt work with the 9070 series. So just to be clear, we used the review driver to review the 9070, because we had to.
comments.author: @Hardwareunboxed

comments.text: Thx Steve
comments.author: @lagarttemido

comments.text: Should we expect a little more performance with the new driver?
comments.author: @finnba_h

comments.text: @finnba_h we are using the latest driver!
comments.author: @Hardwareunboxed

comments.text: But why the lower 9070 XT scores vs 'most' other reviews?
comments.author: @jarnhand266

comments.text: @jarnhand266 why do review results vary? A good number of reasons but looking around at most of the reviewers I follow the data seems similar. I just watched eTeknix's and they got very similar data. Someone told me der8auer got better results, so I go look and find much of the same, very weak CS2 performance for example.
comments.author: @Hardwareunboxed

comments.text: @Hardwareunboxed ah okay. It surprised me that the cs2 performance werent that good. So Im hoping future driver updates bring a boost in performance. As thats my main game and based on these results, it doesnt seem worth getting the card.
comments.author: @aerwicktv

comments.text: @jarnhand266 missing ROP's ???  lol
comments.author: @aykutelmasamaelmasyok7929

comments.text: @Hardwareunboxed What actual XT model was used in the graphs?  I assume it was the XFX Mercury Gaming White shown at the end of the video... but was that an OC or Non-OC variant...or a different model?

comments.text: GN got much better performance in Starfield for some reason.
comments.author: @thefahednassar

comments.text: @thefahednassar Starfield performance can vary quite significantly depending on where you test the game. We've found the town section we use very demanding. I'm not sure where GN test, I'd have to ask Steve, but I assume somewhere else.

comments.text: @Hardwareunboxed Did you downclock that card?

@tim3172

comments.text:
@Hardwareunboxed I am of course referring to 9070 performance relative to other cards like the 7900 XTX. In your review I would say the 9070 XT is quite a bit lower then the 7900 XTX, but if I look at for example TPU review, its much closer to the 7900 XTX performance, also in same game like Space Marine 2.
But I am sleep depraved so I may be missing something, but there are also several other people noticing the same...

comments.text: The comparison with the 7900GRE was not done right. The lower percentage than the one AMD published is due to using the 9070xt as a reference. comments.text:
2 weeks after launch, in the UK you can find the on shelf price for the 9070XT at 691. For US viewers the price includes VAT (Value Added Tax) at 20%. That's the XFX Quicksilver model. Then the price jumps to 728 for Gigabyte and PowerColor variants. So there goes that $50 subsidy already.
For me I hope that the consumer demand drops and AMD provide a GPU+CPU bundle for a decent price (as in below the MSRP of the individual parts) as an uplift for existing mobos. It's the only way I can justify spending so much, otherwise it's another generation skip. Looks like AMD managed to do it. Yep they shot their foot again following nGreedia, but then they only seem to care about keeping the shareholders happy with no real zest for disturbing the market.

comments.text: Based on historical GPU releases from 2010-2019, like the GTX 970 (2014) and RX 580 (2017), prices typically took 2-4 months to stabilize near MSRP after launch, assuming no major external disruptions. Initial markups of 20-30% often eased as supply ramped up, with NVIDIA and AMD historically hitting demand equilibrium around 3-6 months post-release for mid-range cards. For the RX 9070 XT, launched March 6, 2025, with current $130+ premiums, prices could near its $599 MSRP by May-July 2025, and supply might meet demand by August-September 2025, barring scalping or production issues. -Grok

comments.text:
6:14 - As a long time Counter-Strike player and a follower of your channel, let me explain something... The game is terribly optimized and should NOT be included in the benchmarks out of the box. The reason being - it has terrible 1% lows on ANY possible configuration because of its engine. CS2 is one of the rare games where capping your FPS via RTSS makes the frametime graph WAY SMOOTHER. Capping it ingame has no effect. From my testing, capping it via nVidia control panel also didn't work as expected, but maybe with the new control panel works now, haven't tested...

Regardless, if you want to properly test CS2 you have to cap the FPS to below the max framerate a GPU can achieve. I'd say 350 should be achievable for most GPUs, which would mean the only difference would be their minimum FPS.

And this leads me to the whole point why I'm writing this comment. The average FPS for the 9070 XT is obviously a driver issue which would eventually get fixed (just like with the 7900 XTX), but what we need to be looking at is the 1% lows, which on the 4k graph is on par with the RTX 4080s (just like in most other games), which are responsible for the smooth gameplay that a game like Counter-Strike MUST HAVE.

I bet (and also wish to see) that if you retest this game with the FPS capped, you'll get a much better graph.
comments.author: @oldschoolmk7056

comments.text: I have thought about it some more and have realised the NZ price isn't as bad as I first thought. When account for the fact we have a tax called Goods and Services Tax (or GST) that adds 15% to the price of goods, the price doesn't seem so bad compared to the US MSRP. The GST exclusive price converts to roughly US$655. That is actually only 9.17% more than the US MSRP. Even the GST inclusive price converts to about US$753. That is only 25.5% more. For such a tiny market as NZ (a population of 5.2 million people) to have a 9.17% markup before GST and a 25.5% markup after GST is actually not bad.

comments.text:
NewEgg-Gigabyte 9070XT Inventory Debacle:
I got messed over by NewEgg and/or Gigabyte this morning. After staying up super late and waking up super early, spamming online stores for inventory to appear and subsequently attempting to purchase a couple different $600 9070XT models only to receive an out-of-stock notification during processing, I was finally able to purchase the GIGABYTE Gaming Radeon RX 9070 XT 16GB GDDR6 PCI Express 5.0 x16 Graphcis Card GV-R9070XTGAMING OC-16GD. 
Yesterday I set up a Trade-in for my current GPU in preparation for the upgrade. My transaction was completed this morning (3/6/2025) prior to 8:30AM Central Time. 
I received three emails from NewEgg this morning:
1. 8:29AM We received your Trade-in Form
2. 8:59AM Order confirmed: Newegg order #577 (1 item)
3. 9:05AM Order cancelled due to insufficient stock
Apparently, it took NewEgg 30 full minutes to process my order. By that timeunbeknownst to memy GPU was sold to another customer (possibly someone who did not have a trade-in offer). Meanwhile, I went about my day, thinking that I had secured my GPU and allowing 100% of all 9070XT models to be depleted. So now I have no GPU coming, and I have the pleasure of hoping NewEgg will honor the purchase agreement so that I wont have to pay an additional $100 (who knows?) whenever inventory is replenished.
Make this right, NewEgg!

UPDATE:
I did chat with 2 representatives, and they have guaranteed my same purchase price whenever this specific GPU is back in stock. But I will have to reach out to them after my purchase to initiate a refund for whatever amount it costs in excess of that original price.

I don't care about cards priced 2 to 5 thousand.,, or even anything 4 digit, but if we would get a good market in the future for cards at 3 digit price points that's good enough for 99%, so I sincerely hope Amd and Intel can pull soem miracles and with their tiny budgets comparatively to Nvidia, can still find solutions to be competitive.

comments.text:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts on the video! I genuinely appreciate your feedback. Its clear that you found the pacing a bit off, and I understand how that can detract from the overall experience, especially when discussing a complex topic like graphics cards.

The comparison between the 9070XT and the 5070Ti is indeed intricate, and I aimed to highlight the ray tracing capabilities as they are increasingly relevant in today's gaming landscape. However, I see how that might have overshadowed other important aspects of the 9070XTs performance that deserved more attention.

Your mention of other reviewers providing better coverage is valuable. If you have specific points or insights they highlighted that you found particularly useful, Id love to hear them! This kind of constructive criticism is incredibly helpful as I strive to create content that resonates with viewers interests and needs.

Im committed to improving and ensuring that future videos provide a more balanced view, so your input will certainly guide me in that direction. Thanks again for taking the time to share your perspective!

Also, I love lamp.

comments.text:
I suspect a few games chosen for this review would probably prove to be outliers against the complete library of "all modern games", and in a total test battery of "only" sixteen games that was probably pulled the 9070XT down a bit, even with another game that was an apparent outlier against the 5070ti. Some games may improve with driver updates, CS2 in particular.

Even so, I think the results of most reviews are just a little bit middling compared to the anticipation that had been built in the last couple months. We heard a lot about the 9070XT approaching 4080 Super-like raster and are instead met with something closer to the 7900XT. Not a huge difference and it doesn't change my mind on whether or not this is a good product at $600, but it does make it much less compelling if (when?) the effective MSRP is $650 or more. AMD had better have more improvements via driver updates ahead, in my opinion.

But I guess when Nvidia is inflating 5070ti prices to nearly $1K the value argument of the 9070XT may end up conserved. And while it isn't addressed in this review, the much-improved upscaling in a card that often feels just a bit shy of being a full 4K card is quite nice to finally see.

comments.text:
Am I the only one that's a bit surprised and concerned about the temperatures? Specifically the Core to Hotspot Delta? 
We know  the Sapphires, ASUS and I believe ASRock all use PTM, presumably original Honeywell 0.25mm PTM7950 and that its strength is better contact and thus smaller deltas between the core and hotspot which can make the clocks boost higher and temps scale more predictably with fan speed.

So then why is the difference so great? 23C for the Pure, 26C for the Nitro, 27C for the ASUS and 29C for the ASRock? Granted, are these like the max readings, or the average readings?
Usually most people who swapped out past for PTM for RDNA3 dropped their deltas to ~15C-20C at most which gave the cards additional headroom to boost higher.

Now, I know PTM supposedly lasts longer than normal paste and isn't prone to pumping out, but I'm a bit skeptical about clock stability as well as missing headroom in the long run with these deltas. 

I've personally bought a 7800XT Nitro back in November, and the delta has already risen from a decent 18C-20C to nearly 30C. And before you tell me "it's normal"...no it  isn't...as this has already started eating into my core clock. I tested the same load with a normal fan curve and with a 100% fan curve, and even at 100% fan speed, the hotspot refuses to drop below 78C, while the core sits at ~50C. The core clock however does consistently boost 100-150MHz higher thanks to the added headroom, as is expected. Still, to have a 78C temp while the card is at 100% fan speed screams poor contact...and I thought PTM might do the job, once it's out of warranty or if the performance loss becomes too harsh, to the point where I'll disassemble it anyway.

So, what's going on with the 9070s?

Hi, from an Nvidia owner =)

I have a 3060ti. 2025 was supposed to be an upgrade year for me. Looking for at least 50% improvement for longterm 1080p and beyond. I was looking at getting either a 5070 or 5070ti, with the intent of keeping whatever I get for 4 years or more.

comments.text:
it's not exactly cut down. while yes it's true there is less physical hardware features on the card it's a different architecture. RDNA 3 is a massive chip with a little chiplets on it for different parts of the GPU. RDNA4 has gone back to monolithic design. so it's hard to compare the two. 

this doesn't rule out an XTX possibility. but I think it will be the top of the line card in all fairness and no XTX will come. Next up is UDNA and that may offer complete range of products. 

I do personally think we will see cards using this chip with more VRAM down the road.

Another weak set of card releases in my opinion.

This new generation has been really underwhelming.

It was clear when the RTX 4090 was released that there was still some work to do with 4K, so I thought the entire point of the 5000 series was to bridge that gap.

This just looks to me almost like a mid-gen refresh of all the mid range cards to be very slightly faster and sell us this frame gen rubbish, which will be incredibly hit and miss.

I'm not going to bother and will await the 6000 series.

comments.text:
OH NO! STEVE IS STANDING!!! Oh wait, it's a fakeout! Thank God! Very good and impartial review. Giving AMD their due props while being realistic and not blowing smoke up their rear ends. Laying all the cards down for us and letting we, your viewers, come to our own purchasing decision.  The 9070 XT is IMHO rightly named by AMD, it's not quite at the 7900 XTX level and is more like an updated 7900 XT. However, the price is more than fair and it trades blows with the 4070 Ti Super while coming tantalizingly close to the 5070 Ti in raster. Ray tracing is definitely improved, although not at NVIDIA's level, but I don't imagine people would want to play at 4K with ray-tracing with any card at this mid-range level anyway as the performance hit is not worth the visual upgrade. 

I agree with every reviewer -- AMD has a tremendous opportunity here to grab the entire mid-range market and a great deal of mindshare all to themselves. For my part, I have decided to support AMD but went with an XFX 310 Merc Speedster 7900 XTX as I'm not sold on ray-tracing in games at all yet when comparing the visual difference vs. the performance hit and I really wanted the higher raster ability and memory capacity. Regardless, they have my money and support and I hope they do well with these cards. And if newfound success leads them to decide to go for a 9080 XT or even a 9090 XT then I'm right there with them.

Shoot, considering the price of the 9070 is in line with the 5070 (non-Ti), frequently comparing it to the 5070 Ti is just overkill.  Performance sometimes matching a $250+ more expensive GPU makes the choice easy.  If money isn't a total roadblock, then 5080 (<=1300), 5090 (<=2300), 9070 (<=800), and if I get desperate to get something before tariffs are enacted against GPUs then I'll consider a 5070 Ti (<=850).  But I like the 9070 enough that I'll try to make a run at it tomorrow.

And frames over 90 FPS is fine.  60 min preferred, 40+ absolute minimum.  I don't care if the FPS is 25% lower if it's clocking 120+.  Just a question of how newer games run, and hopefully they get more optimized as AMD gains a bigger foothold in the market again.

comments.text:
AMD fanboy here.

If AMD doesnt supply the 9070XT at $600 and I'm waiting anyway then I'll just be patient and pick up the 5070TI once it hits MSRP and get the better rayteacing+features+game support.

This would be my first team green GPU but at MSRP they're both worth considering.  If AMD had a 9070xtx or a 9080 at $750 that beat the 5070ti but had less features we'd be talking.  Lacking that though the 5070ti is worth considering IMO, because the extra $150 you're spending on features from team green cant be converted to performance with team red if they dont offer that level of card.

So the way I see it is the performance class of both is worth $600, but you can pay an extra $150 for better ray tracing, multi-frame generation, upscaling (presumably), video encoding, proffesional workloads, and LLM support (plus a few extras like better game feature support by developers etc).

I find those features to be worth $150, but i also dont find them to be deal belreakers.  With that said I think the first one to actually sell at MSRP gets my vote this time around.

If only that price was slightly better. I am impressed, unlike "Blackwell's" Ada plus fast memory kludge, this is a real generation. Improvements to rendering across the board, and the RT improvements make me especially happy--Nvidia's lead has shrunk greatly. Tack on their melting GPUs, fake launches, bald faced market manipulation, and being simps for mega corps (claiming shortages whilst selling GPUs to AI companies by the forklift)...and I am happy that AMD is making competition real.

Ray tracing can get stuffed at this point, I just don't care anymore because the price barrier to entry is unreal. It's an unattainable feature if you have a 1440p monitor but only enough for a 1080p-class GPU. IMO we all bought into RT way too early and drank Nvidia's poisonous market hype. That killed the market unfairly and pushed people to spend unreasonable amounts of money chasing a tech dream of high FPS RT gaming.

comments.text:
$800+ has missed the mark. This is a cost optimissed GPU (256-bit GDDR6 memory). No option for more powerful MCUs (I think 32GB would go down well, and I'm interested in the AI performance). Plus, I believe those XFX Mercs don't have vapour chambers (cooler on the XTX is a champ).

AMD delivered the RX480 8GB for $249 in 2016. They did it again in 2019 for the RX5700, but ~$400. The 6000 series has pricing was crazy. The 7000 series did well after AMD made the prices more reasonable. Wihth Nvidia recent scarcity (I think it is manufactured to make them more sought after), AMD is now selling a lot more 7900s as people have lost patience, and need the VRAM..

AIBs have to add value, but how much value can you add to a 300w GPU? The two seem at odd with each other. I hope this series is to fill a short gap before the next series is rolled out. Feels like AMD forgot they had some homework to do and left it to the last minute, a little like Nvidia. 5/10

comments.text:
It's gonna get interesting. Might actually end up seeing GPUs being cheaper other places than in North America this go around. If tarrifs keep pushing on (and potentially worsen), which does impact general cost of living too - then especially now that the budget end is dead, shelf prices in the US might very well price out everyone but well off adult working gamers with disposable income. I imagine at the 600usd mark, there's really no substantial margin to go around for anyone in the supply chain. Meaning trying to mitigate the price bloat of import-tarrifs coming on top of that, means someone in the supply chain has to take a loss on each sale.

Water cooling is a luxury. But considering the cost of current age beastly coolers, this might be a good time to offer one of those technically-A-cooler-but-not-for-real-use GPU models, with a $10 plastic blower on it. That plus a decent non-RGB block would still be cheaper than just the card. And, waterblocks its one of those things that American small (or large) businesses actually could spin up home-grown production for quite rapidly. It might require importing metal at larger scsle, but it isn't one of those "politicians don't understand current supply chains, it's gonna take 5 years to get established for made-here production" situations. If you got a business with a CNC with some idle time...

comments.text:
There is something screwy going on with performance this generation, on both sides. The margins various outlets find swings heavily. Much more so than 30 vs 6000 and 40 vs 7000 did. TPU has the 9070XT at 25% faster than the GRE... but they also found the 5070 to be as fast as the 4070Ti which is completely absurd when you compare to other sites.

So Steve: PLEASE rush a 40-50 game average as soon as you get a breather. And please consider discarding settings that can't hit 60FPS on either the 5070Ti or 9070XT. These "one completely sucks and the other is outright hilariously bad" tests skews the results and don't reflect how the products will be used... and people buy things to use them, not to benchmark them (Buildzoid notwithstanding).

comments.text: Can someone explain how the 9070xt performs better in 4K then 1440p vs the other cards? I would think if youre behind in 1440p, the deficit would only get larger at 4K, but it seems to be the reverse
comments.author: @Peytonwatson14

comments.text: There are different operations in the rendering pipeline. Higher resolutions hit some parts of that pipeline more than others. So by allocating more or less transistors to those parts of the pipeline, you can tune the card to perform better at those resolutions.

comments.text:
I feel like the 9070 XT is a little over-hyped tbh.

In my opinion, the RX 9070 XT is only great value because of the bad market we're in. Gen on gen wise, the 9070 XT is a X700 XT class GPU based on what % of the die their using, which was $449 last year. And if we judge it based on it's specs rather than how cut down it is (the amount of VRAM and CUs it has) it's most equivalent to a 7800 XT, which was $499. Even when adjusting for inflation since 2022, which we shouldn't be doing because semiconductors are not affected in the same way (see other semiconductor products like other PC parts or phones) that's still $488-542. Their also not using TSMC's cutting edge node like most GPU generations have, which means its much more mature with better yields.


If you look at it as a RX 7900 XTX with a $230 price cut (7900 XTX sold at $830 during its best sales) it seems like great value. However from the HUB review I just watched, at 1440p (4k has better results, but most people using this card will be 1440p users) its more equal to a 7900 XT / 4070 Ti Super, and this is while excluding RT results where we expected 4070 Ti Super but it's more like a 4070 Super on average, dipping down to 4060 Ti in heavy RT workloads. 7900 XT's new use to go for $658, so its 58$ cheaper, or $300 cheaper MSRP wise, which generationally isn't great.


No matter how you slice it, its $50-150 more expensive than it should be. RDNA 3 was already a poorly priced, non-competitive generation, and now we have a price hike. AMD definitely did better than we all expected, since they flop a lot, but that doesn't mean they did great just because we're use to crap. This isn't BAD value, but it's not great value either, its just decent. NVIDIA and this whole market is just so bad average feels amazing right now.


To put this in perspective in a different way; the 5070's closest last gen counterpart is a RTX 4070 Super based on specs, with the 4070 Super actually having a bit more cores, and it got $50 MSRP shaved off. While AMD's closest counterpart spec wise was a 7800 XT, and it got a $100 jump in MSRP.


HUB also mentioned that based on performance per dollar (based off real FPS numbers, not favorable AMD benchmarks) its only 15% better value, and AMD really needs to be at least 20% better value to be really competitive. This is being generous by using mostly raster results too, people care more about RT than they did during RDNA 2 considering games are coming out where you literally can't turn it off. Bad RT performance won't age well if you plan on playing AAA games.


Am I not the only one who thinks the product is a bit overhyped? That it should've been $549? Just wondering, because I feel alone, but I'm using logic and trends to come to my conclusion so I also know I'm not being dumb.
comments.author: @Hybred

comments.text:
No. It's massively overhyped. I'd go as far to say that without the 50 series launch this card would be considered a complete disaster.

comments.author: @vgamedude9811

comments.text: Very well thought-out stuff here. I would temper expectations for future products, personally. The rate of improvement in graphics card performance per dollar over time has been slowing throughout much of the history of these parts. I strongly suspect it has to do with a combination of silicon fabrication becoming increasingly complex/expensive and much of the "low-hanging fruit" already being picked at this point in terms of engineering problems to solve on the microarchitecture side of things. If I'm right, GPUs can't and won't get better at the same rate forever, because there are limits to what's physically possible to make and approaching those limits requires increasingly sophisticated tooling and increasingly difficult architecture optimizations. We've arguably already been seeing that for well over a decade.

comments.text:
As usual all the pre 3rd party testing hype and the released performance numbers from AMD made the 9070xt seem like a direct basic equal to the 5070ti.
The truth of the matter is the 9070xt overall is more of a direct competitor performance wise to the vanilla 5070 which is not at the 5070ti level at all.

Another thing I have noticed on several reviews that sort of surprised me is the AMD 9070XT was drawing a fair amount more power than NVidia's 5070ti card while still underperforming performance wise to the 5070ti at times by a fairly large margin.

The only saving grace for AMD here is that there is there no Nvidia 50 series stock available at all and as a result when or if a 50 series card is offered for sale it is at largely inflated scalper pricing.
This is what AMD may have going for it is if they actually have inventory available for consumers to buy within a normal MSRP range taking into account AIB improvements for the higher priced models over the base cards.

But if a buyer were not in dire need of a GPU and really was looking to get a card with the capabilities of the 5070ti then they would probably be better off to wait out the Nvidia inventory shortage and their prices to drop back to MSRP levels and get the card they actually want.

If AMD does have ample stock of the new 9070xt to sell there will be many buyers that had been unsuccessfully waiting on a 5070ti to be available will go ahead and buy the 9070xt instead which in the future may take some pressure off the later appearing Nvidia stock to come up for purchase.

comments.text: @tubularmonkeymaniac Inflation happened. Remember 6 years ago when a dozen eggs cost $1.29, but now they cost $5.99? An apartment that cost $900 a month 6+ years ago now costs $1,500. A box of crackers that cost $2.99 now costs $4.99 and this applies to 99% of every single thing you can think of. The cost of silicon has gone up, the cost of plastic and metal has gone up, the cost of shipping and manufacturing has gone up, the cost of advertising has gone up, the salary and wages of everyone involved in the GPU supply line has gone up too. Therefore a graphics card costs more now than it did 6 years ago. If a mid range graphics card cost $350 in 2019, the 2025 modern equivalent appears to cost $600+. I don't like, you don't like, but them's the breaks.

comments.text:
As someone who has owned multiple 40 series gpus including the 4080super, and multiple recent Radeon gpus including the 7900xtx, I will likely never purchase an Nvidia gpu again. I returned my 4080 super because of pure dissatisfaction with the performance and nvidia app. The adrenaline app is so much better in almost every way in my opinion. 

Additional pros over nvidia Ive found:

- I can monitor metrics such as hotspot temps, vram usage, etc with ease. 

- I dont need a self combusting power connector.

- I dont have to check to see if all of my cores are present. 

- VRAM is never an issue I ever have to concern myself with in the games I play.

Buy whatever is best for you and what gives you the most bang for your buck in the budget you have to work with. Just dont shy away from AMD cards because of what youve heard from people online.
comments.author: @SippyCup_Official

comments.text:
I completely agree r.e the driver app with nVidia being totally outdated but they are working on a new one which should be better. 

I'm quite surprised you prefer the 7900XTX tbh - that card is slightly faster than the 4080S in raster but absolutely chugs power and has worse upscalers , I do admit I'm not fully happy with the 16GB of memory with my 4080S but DLSS is a massive boon. 

nVidia have absolutely phoned it in with these Blackwell cards - and I agree with you on that. Rubin (next gen?) had better be much better for me to consider upgrading then. I hope the AI bubble bursts and then we'll see what they can do.
comments.author: @tourmaline07

comments.text:
@tourmaline07 I may be the outlier but in my personal opinion dlss is no good. Dlss4 isnt supported in the games I play, including driver level override. DLSS3.5  doesnt produce a better or equal picture quality in the games I do play, and doesnt provide any noticeable improvements worth the trades offs of switching to nvidia. 

Its very weird that now Nvidia has the truly awful app that some folks on the forums are insisting will age like fine wine. I feel like they have traded places with AMD and nobody noticed. 

Regarding power, I undervolt and run low fan speeds to keep noise and thermals down. Unless the user lives in a region where power costs are 10x higher than North America, I do not see the power draw being an issue personally. 

For the quality of life and NOTICEABLE gaming performance I really dont see any other options than the AMD cards at any price point under $1500 USD. I never thought I would say that as a former never Radeon Nvidia fan like myself but Im firmly planted in camp AMD for the foreseeable future. 

Like I said previously, I may be an outlier and these are my personal opinions so take what I say with a 5090 sized grain of salt LOL.

comments.text:
I made it half way through the review before I wondered why you are comparing a $600 msrp card with a $750 msrp card and seem kind of disappointed that the 9070XT is behind the RTX 5070 Ti most of the time. I think it's fine to mention how they stack up, but the RTX 5070 is much closer in price to the RX 9070 XT (especially considering the elevated prices on Nvidia's side), yes I understand that would make the future comparison between the RX 9070 and the RTX 5070 awkward, but I don't really care. These two companies have made their beds and now they need to lay in them.

Edit: I understand that you don't want to compare the RX 9070 XT to the RTX 5070 since the latter is such a dog, but it is the closest price comparison. To me it looks like you're doing Nvidia a favor by not comparing the 9070 XT to it's closest priced competition, the RTX 5070. 
I can now see why some people in the comments say your channel seems to favor Nvidia

Edit 2: A suggestion, maybe open up with MSRP and pricing expectations before the numbers, because that would add context to the comparison. Because if $600 is only a temporary price, that would make the comparison to the RTX 5070 Ti more understandable.

It's a little harsh to keep comparing it to the 5070Ti just because 750 is it's supposed MSRP. Here in the UK the cheapest 5070 I can see listed is 679 and the cheapest 9070XT 579. This means that it is very much up against the 5070 price-wise and not to 5070Ti which is listed at over 900, and in that case it's not even close which GPU you should buy. It's a bit like comparing a 7600XT to a 4070 Super and saying it's not as good.
The bigger picture is that it's just not very exciting - 7900XT performance with better RT 2 years later for 50 less is hardly something to celebrate. AMD really had a chance to lay waste to Nvidia by pricing this at 500, still it's an easy purchase decision in the current market. 
What I find amazing though is websites like Overclockers not even mentioning the 9070XT on their homepage, instead an oversized banner saying "RTX 5070 - Game Changer" This means that unless you take the time to educate yourself the default purchase will still be the more expensive, inferior Nvidia product for most. Don't believe me? A friend at work just bought a 5080 to replace his 4090 because bigger number better. Didn't even look at any reviews.

comments.text:
Reviewers are still using these fake MSRPs to mislead consumers...
The bottom line is RTX 5070 Ti starts from $900, while 9070XT will probably start from $650. 9070XT is good deal, especially if you don't care that much about RT. The reality with RT is that AMD had bad performance for so many years, many games were not optimized for their cards. Also DLSS is supported in more games then FSR4. It will take time not just for the AMD hardware, but also games and drivers to catch up. Another issue AMD is working on - unification of the compute and gaming architecture. With NVIDIA, you get CUDA on gaming hardware, making them appealing for general computing. And yet another issue AMD must address with RDNA5 - high power consumption. 25% premium for RTX 5070 Ti sounds right to me, I would agree with the MSRPs of these two cards. The only problem is - they are not real. If AMD make their MSRP more real, they win.

comments.text:
@mojojojo6292 I will try to address your points as best as I can,
 but I would like to remind you my perspective is focused on the experience of a hardware enthusiast and gamer.

First, I already noted that DLSS and DLAA IMO are by far the main differenciator for Nvidia vs AMD.
I also don't dispute FSR support is mediocre at best, but what did you expect at 10% marketshare?

Secondly, I have been hearing a lot about RTX HDR and I had to do some quick research.
It seems to me to be a nice feature to have, but by not means a "must have" feature,
I would hazard a guess that the quality of the screen you play on makes a bigger difference while playing games than RTX HDR.

As for future set i could just start rambling off acranyms too, Radeon Boost, Chill, RSR, FMF 2, but in the end the only thing of real use to me is anti-lag/reflex.

What annoys me most though is that people worry about missing out on X Nvidia software feature, just the same as we did a decade ago for hairworks and physX, look what happened to that! 
We can look back now and say that was just a gimmick, but it sure did sell graphics cards.

My conclusion is, if you are using your GPU for work/productivity and you write it off on your business, buy Nvidia.
If your main focus in just gaming/entertainment, the numbers just don't add up to me and the advantage is minimal.

In the end we need a healthy AMD and Nvidia or we will all be priced out.
comments.author: @ccredmansvids

Obviously pricing is the major factor in the conversation so we will see how that goes, but in my local currency a 5070ti is $2k and a 9070XT is expected to be around $1,200. Even with gouging it is likely to be significantly cheaper than the Nvidia option. Game availability is really the only major con, one should not buy a product on future promises ofcourse, but historically AMD has been a safe bet on expanding their support.

comments.text:
@mojojojo6292 Market share is such a horrible metric to use for this specific topic. Market share is determined by previous performance, not new releases. Those features are niche, whichever way you swing it, if they provide value to your purchase decision then that is great, but that does not hold true for everyone. Personally I have used RTX HDR exactly twice and don't feel the need to use it in my games. Most consumers care about upscaling and framerate, that's as deep as their required features goes.

FSR 4 much better than DLSS CNN model and approaching Transformer model clarity with similiar performance. It doesn't do as well for small details in motion, but has better overall clarify on that object in motion and has similiar visual quality on static or slow moving objects. The DF conclusion was literally that it is much better than FSR3/DLSS 3 and comparable to DLSS 4. I am not saying it is better than DLSS4, but it is certainly not enough difference to be worth the price gap for comparably performing GPU's.

Second comment: It's strange that the 9070 XT can pull up quite near to 5070 Ti on 4K, but drops away on 1440p.

The RDNA4 architecture is different enough to RDNA3 that if the code is not optimized for the former, it will likely add too much wait states or something like that (programming artifacts due to having to handle the multichip latency of RDNA3)

comments.text:
Really should be comparing it to the 5070 since it's much closer in price that the 5070ti. Especially the real world pricing of the 5070ti. 
Cheapest in stock 5070ti in Australia is $1900. Utterly ridiculous for a card that has an MSRP of $1509 here.
Ill be curious to see what the 9070 XT retails for in Australia.
I thought it was launching tonight at midnight so I was on PCCG and other sites refreshing frantically. PCCG already has the cards up on the site. The site got absolutely hammered at midnight and barely responded to refreshes making me think bots were trying to grab the 9070 XT.
But it only last about 4 minutes and they all switched off when it became apparent the sale was not happening tonight.

Still if the 5070ti existed at MSRP no one would be buying the 9070 XT at it's MSRP. I would say the step up in performance especially in RT and the better DLSS quality is worth the extra money. But it's not a real MSRP so it's irrelevant.

The other thing is the 7900 XT was selling for more than a year for $1100 in Australia before supply dried up. That roughly equates to a US$550 price as our price is usually double the US price. That makes this new gen a bit of a nothing burger. You could of gotten basically the same performance for over a year, for a cheaper price.

It better not be more than $1200 over here.

Ok, seeing this I can say that I am kind of disappointed, as was looking to it as an upgrade for my 3080Ti:
1. In 4K it is doing better compared to competition, 5070Ti
2. It is definitely not on par with 5070Ti
3. RT is not as good as I was hoping for
Having USD1K budget, and 5080 being out of reach not worth all-an-all, I think the closest option as upgrade path for 3080Ti, as I see is (priority wise):
1. 4080 Super, if I manage to get it below USD850 (second hand)
2. 5070Ti, if manage to get it around MSRP
3. 9070 XT, if around MSRP, though not sure if this is now a good option 
Otherwise, price wise AMD got it close to right, very good and not being greedy, but $100 less will make it more compelling to new users.
Just wish they also had 9080 XT for $750 - performance on-par or beating 4080 Super. :)

comments.text:
Ok.. so here are the GPUs and CPUs that I have at my disposal and "in hand" for my gaming/office PC needs.  For Nvidia, I have an RTX 3090, RTX 3080TI, RTX 4070TI, RTX 4070, and 20, 30, and 40 series 60 class cards.  On the AMD side, I have a 7900GRE, 6950XT, 6800XT, 7600, and various 6000 and 500 series cards.  On the CPU side, I have a 7700x, 13700k, 12900k, 5950x, 5700x3d, and various other AM4 class CPUs.  In my very basic testing and evaluation for the e-sports games I play and the content creation work that I do...  Is there ANY driving reason to upgrade to either of the current-gen offerings from AMD or Nvidia?  I've put my 7700x with my 7900gre and my 13700K with my 3090.  Both systems seem to run just fine and deliver performance beyond my limits.   Dialing that down and using my 5700x3d and a 6800xt or my rtx 4070 delivers the same usability.  So again, is all this just a much of a muchness for folks that have reasonable spec systems from the last couple of generations?  Where would someone need to be to really NEED to upgrade to anything coming out right now?  I guess that's the real question for me.  Beyond FOMO, what is the "real world" benefit to the average gamer?  Leaving aside someone who's looking to play the most demanding games that require the new hardware. 

Thanks
Rick

My next card will be an RT focused purchase I suspect but paying 1000+ for a handful of games to have some nicer lighting is as insane as it was last week.

Don't understand the excitement personally other than the RT side of things this is the same price/performance as has been the street price reality from AMD for like 6 months (I think longer but I'm not checking price history graphs for this comment) and the RT isn't good enough to say that significantly changes anything. comments.text: Wafer prices have more than tripled. Rx480 era 16nm finfet wafers were $5000, now 5nm wafers are $16-17000.   EUV Lithography machines are 4x the price OF DUV machines.  Validating and designing chips on newer nodes are significantly more expensive compared to the past.  Sure Nvidia and to a lesser extent TSMC and fab equipment makers are demanding higher margins, but the real big culprit is its costing more to make chips on smaller and smaller nodes.

comments.text: Well, you can still buy a GPU that smokes an RX480 for $200, so compared to that it would not be that high.  The RX480 was 6 Teraflops.  The RX 9070XT is 97 Teraflops.  So in $ per Teraflop, we drop from ~$33 to $6 per Teraflop.  I dont think we can say inflation is insane

comments.text:
It is honestly. Tech needs to either increase performance and maintain price or increase efficiency to bring about lower costs, look at the TV and cellphone industry for prime examples. 

Generational improvement isn't always raising the bar, it's sometimes just making what was once out of reach more affordable/accessible.

Nvidia tossed this out the window and brought marginal improvements for ridiculous price increases. So they didn't take either approach, which is why ppl are disappointed. AMD leaned more into efficiency for lower costs, not mind blowingly low ofc, but a trend in a preferrable direction.

comments.text: I don't think it's stupid at all. I think it's absolutely brilliant. What's the main point of marketing? To draw people's attention to your product. And hey, it worked - it got the attention of all you guys (and the attention of many others commenting in this and other videos about this product). Now imagine after you finished watching the video, a psychologist appears in front of you in a puff of smoke, snaps his fingers, and asks "without rewinding the video, tell me the name of a product featured in it that immediately springs to mind?". I bet most of you would answer "Sapphire Pure. Or was it Puke?". Don't underestimate the psychological manipulation of these marketers, if you're not careful with your mental discipline they will make you buy tons of crap you don't need (with money you don't have, to impress people you don't like) with their trickery.

comments.text:
After I hit refresh I had a choice of two 9070 reviews to watch, this one or Der8auer's. I picked this one, and its sponsored by Thermal Grizzly, so I guess Roman got me either way. First impressions a couple of minutes in, I think Sapphire should perhaps revisit the box art on their 'PUKE' card.
Edit: Wow, hotspot temperatures, what a novel idea!
Final thoughts, despite some misgivings, it still feels pretty positive. I'm not in the market, because I already have a 4070S, but if I were still struggling along on my old 1070, and unwilling to wait yet another gen, I think I'd probably go for this over anything in the 50 series, despite DLSS/FSR, pending the actual street price.

comments.text: @logan62097  I'm in a similar boat (6750XT), I don't feel like it's worth for me to upgrade right now (especially since I would also need to upgrade my 5800X in order to not be bottlenecked at 1080p). Usually I upgrade when I can get at least double the performance for roughly the same price (before the 6750XT I had a 1070), and the 9700XT doesn't seem like it's consistently double the performance in raster. I don't really have any performance problems with the 6750XT in the games I play as long as I turn off raytracing (recently I played through Resident Evil 2 and 3 Remakes and Horizon Forbidden West), so I think I will wait for UDNA and keep my 6750XT a year or two more (and save some additional money for a complete CPU/MB/RAM/GPU/Case upgrade).
